meaning_mnemonic: If you travel to the <radical>fish</radical> <radical>capital</radical>, you'll find the leader of all fish, the mighty <kanji>whale</kanji>! Okay, so a whale isn't technically a fish, but that's why it makes such a good leader. You can usually only find whales hanging around near the capital because they really enjoy ruling over all the other fish. They are the biggest, after all.
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>whale</kanji> who resides over the capital just happens to be <reading>gay</reading> (げい). You only know this because his husband is a man whale too. Actually, now that you think about it, all the whales you've ever met have been gay.

meaning_mnemonic: Clearing his <radical>flowers</radical> of <radical>icicle</radical>s, the <radical>samurai</radical> returns home to his <kanji>villa</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: Once the samurai enters the <kanji>villa</kanji>, he lets his <reading>soul</reading> (そう) go. He's been fighting for long enough and this villa was always where he wanted to go.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>drunkard</radical> gets his hands on a <radical>plow</radical> and starts <kanji>planting</kanji> right away. Drunk people are surprisingly good at planting, especially when they have machines to help them do it.
reading_mnemonic: He keeps <kanji>planting</kanji> and planting... a little too much. You walk over and realize this drunkard isn't just any guy... he's YOUR <reading>CY</reading>BORG (さい)!

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>mouth</radical> with a <radical>sword</radical> is threatening to cut off your <radical>fingers</radical> because they've <kanji>kidnap</kanji>ped you! You can't see anything about them, since they're all covered up. All you see is their angry mouth and the sword they keep putting near your fingers.
reading_mnemonic: You've been <kanji>kidnap</kanji>ped and your kidnapper has asked for one thing in exchange for your safe return: a <reading>kay</reading>ak (かい). Kayaks are expensive. And it's way easier for this dude to kidnap you and demand your family buy one and give it to them than for them to work for one.

meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>forehead</radical> is the <radical>origin</radical> for the <radical>measurement</radical> for your <kanji>crown</kanji>! If you measure somewhere else on your head for a crown it won't fit.
reading_mnemonic: You want your <kanji>crown</kanji> to be just like Genghis <reading>Khan</reading>'s (かん), which was more of a cap. He's your hero though, because he ruled over the most people, so you want yours to match his measurements.

meaning_mnemonic: You're in a really important position, <radical>heavy</radical> with <radical>power</radical>, but you can't carry all of that around with you, so you <radical>boil</radical> it all down to just a few <kanji>merit</kanji>s.
reading_mnemonic: The only problem with consolidating your <kanji>merit</kanji>s like this is that rac<reading>coon</reading>s (くん) are always trying to steal them. Raccoons really like shiny, small things. Like, say, the physical representation of all your personal and professional merits.

meaning_mnemonic: You took someone's <radical>alcohol</radical> and <radical>drop</radical> <radical>drop</radical> <radical>drop</radical>'d it all into the <radical>river</radical>. Now you have to <kanji>repay</kanji> them. Alcohol costs a lot of money, you know.
reading_mnemonic: In order to <kanji>repay</kanji> them for the alcohol you wasted, you offer to give them your <reading>shoe</reading>s (しゅう). They don't want your shoes though, so you have to bring them to a store and watch them try on a bunch of different pairs so you can repay them that way.

meaning_mnemonic: You use <radical>thread</radical> and <radical>writing</radical> to sew our <kanji>family crest</kanji>. You've been sewing your family crest since you were a kid, you could do it today with your eyes closed.
reading_mnemonic: Your <kanji>family crest</kanji> is of a <reading>mon</reading>ster! (もん) And the writing says "Our Family Monster."

meaning_mnemonic: At <radical>noon</radical> you <radical>stop</radical> to buy <radical>stamp</radical>s because that's the only time they're being sold at <kanji>wholesale</kanji> price. Everyone's so busy eating and working and being at school, that they miss this awesome deal, but not you. Everyday at noon you stock up on wholesale stamps. Do you send a lot of mail? No, you probably just collect them. But they were cheap, so who cares!
reading_mnemonic: Oh, one more thing. Going at noon isn't enough, you have to say the password to get them at <kanji>wholesale</kanji> price too. The password is "<reading>Oh Roshi</reading>" (おろし). Okay, so maybe that's just the name of the guy there, but it always works when I want to get stamps wholesale so you should do it too!

meaning_mnemonic: You see a bunch of <radical>tree</radical>s lined up outside of the <radical>gate</radical> to the <radical>east</radical> and realize they look like perfect <kanji>column</kanji>s. It seems like a building or a castle should be resting above them.
reading_mnemonic: Out of the tree <kanji>column</kanji>s bursts professional wrestler <reading>Ran</reading>dy (らん) Savage! "Oooh I'm talking about columns that I like mmmm oh yeaah. The Macho Man loves columns MMm OOHH YEAAH~!"

meaning_mnemonic: Jump on a <radical>scooter</radical> to <radical>excuse</radical> yourself from answering a question and you've successfully <kanji>deviate</kanji>d from that nosey person's plan! You've also been able to <kanji>elude</kanji> them pretty well.
reading_mnemonic: You <kanji>deviate</kanji> from the plan a little too well, and as you're scooting, what you've done <reading>eats</reading> (いつ) away at you. You feel guilty for eluding them...

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>triceratops</radical> with a <radical>mustache</radical> will go on talking forever. Every time you think he's done he says, "<kanji>Furthermore</kanji>..." and keeps going. Something about a mustache on a dinosaur makes him kind of a jerk, but he's held in such high <kanji>esteem</kanji> that no one ever interrupts him.
reading_mnemonic: Why don't you just interrupt this mustache triceratops while he's saying <kanji>furthermore</kanji>? Because he's the <reading>Shou</reading>gun's (しょう) pet. If you interrupt him you'll probably be put to death or something. Just let him keep going and hope he runs out of furthermores to talk about.

meaning_mnemonic: When the <radical>sun</radical> comes up the <radical>spikes</radical> of <radical>geoduck</radical>s <kanji>appear</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: You watch these spikes <kanji>appear</kanji> and suddenly <reading>Ken</reading> (けん)the samurai also appears next to you. "I DID IT!" he shouts, "I've learned how to appear out of thin air!"

meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Wolverine</radical> puts a <radical>stick</radical> between his <radical>legs</radical> and straight into some <radical>rice</radical>, all while wearing a <kanji>solemn</kanji> expression on his face. He's probably remembering his dad who died from getting his legs stuck in rice. Just leave the poor solemn creature alone.
reading_mnemonic: When you first saw how <kanji>solemn</kanji> Wolverine was after his dad died, it really <reading>shook</reading> (しゅく) you. Now you're used to always seeing him emotionally cold and distant. It might be time to shake that solemnity out of him though.

meaning_mnemonic: If you give <radical>Splinter</radical> your <radical>heart</radical> you'll feel pretty <kanji>foolish</kanji> afterwards. His heart belongs to the art of ninjutsu!
reading_mnemonic: Splinter tells you to your face how <kanji>foolish</kanji> you are and you feel your heart turn to <reading>goo</reading> (ぐ). Now you can't even give it to someone else. No one wants goo.

meaning_mnemonic: Who goes into their <radical>yurt</radical> to <radical>boil</radical> things? The <kanji>common</kanji> people! <kanji>All sorts</kanji> of people do it, it's really common. You don't boil things outside, do you?
reading_mnemonic: Here, the <kanji>common</kanji> people all do this, so just let me <reading>show</reading> (しょ) you how. First you go into your yurt, and… Hey, pay attention and watch what I'm showing you!

meaning_mnemonic: Whenever you set <radical>foot</radical> in a <radical>bar</radical>, there's always something new to <kanji>practice</kanji>. If you usually drink a lot, you might want to practice moderation for example. Or perhaps you simply want to brush up on your social skills. Either way, plenty of opportunities for practice.
reading_mnemonic: This type of <kanji>practice</kanji> is especially hard for you because you're a <reading>cen</reading>taur (せん). You only have hooves for feet, and balancing on a bar is going to be a huge hurdle. But your teacher promised if you practiced enough you could make it, and here you are! With your hoofed foot on the bar!

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>Mouth</radical> <radical>King</radical>, who is just one big mouth, has one skill, and that is to <kanji>present</kanji>. That big mouth is always presenting something.
reading_mnemonic: "I will <kanji>present</kanji> to you a presentation about mouths, but I require energy. Please fill my giant mouth body with delicious <reading>ta</reading>ter (てい) tots.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>coat rack</radical> will turn into a <radical>bundle</radical> of sticks if you <kanji>neglect</kanji> it. When you neglect a coat rack, the weight from the coats will pull all of the arms off, leaving it as a <kanji>sparse</kanji> stick.
reading_mnemonic: You go up to the <kanji>neglect</kanji>ed coat rack and try to make things right by cleaning it with <reading>so</reading>ap (そ). But no matter how much you scrub, it won't get clean, the arms won't go back on.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>sick</radical>ness that hits you like an <radical>arrow</radical> will do its gross work <kanji>rapidly</kanji>. It's not a good thing, you're gonna get really sick really fast.
reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>rapid</kanji> sickness makes your head pound like there's a <reading>shih tzu</reading> (しつ) yapping and barking nonstop. And it's making you sh*t a lot.

meaning_mnemonic: Whatever you <radical>say</radical> through a <radical>satellite</radical> turns into <kanji>Noh chanting</kanji>. It gets all drawn out and distorted from going through the satellite, which makes it SOUND like Noh chanting at least.
reading_mnemonic: While you're fake <kanji>Noh chanting</kanji> you have to pause every few minutes to take a bite of <reading>yo</reading>gurt (よう). Yogurt is good for the throat! At least you think it is. It's not like you're actually chanting, the satellite is doing all the real work.

meaning_mnemonic: You cast the <radical>Mona Lisa</radical> in <radical>gold</radical> and attach it to a stick to turn it into a <kanji>sickle</kanji>! It's really big and bulky, but when you swing it fast enough your new sickle cuts lots of wheat! Just don't tell anyone what you did with the famous Mona Lisa painting and you should be able to get away with this!
reading_mnemonic: Now that you've turned the Mona Lisa into a <kanji>sickle</kanji>, you have to change the little description under its name in the Louvre. You draw a giant <reading>comma</reading> (かま) next to "Mona Lisa" and write "THE SICKLE." Then you shove it back on the wall as best you can.

meaning_mnemonic: If you <radical>announce</radical> that <radical>alcohol</radical> is illegal you're just being <kanji>cruel</kanji>. Honestly, saying no one can have any alcohol at all is totally <kanji>unjust</kanji>. They tried that in the 1920s and it didn't work then either, so cut it out! Let people drink what they want to drink!
reading_mnemonic: After this <kanji>cruel</kanji> announcement is made everyone will turn to the next best thing after alcohol. <reading>Coke</reading> (こく)! It's not a replacement, but if this unjust law won't change, then coke sales are going to go through the roof.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>surplus</radical> <radical>stool</radical>, please <kanji>describe</kanji> it.
reading_mnemonic: You <kanji>describe</kanji> the features of the stool to <reading>Jo</reading>-Anne (じょ).

meaning_mnemonic: If you want to wear a <radical>top hat</radical> you <kanji>also</kanji> have to wear a suit to go with it. You can't just wear a top hat, that just doesn't look right. When you think top hat, think about what you also need with it.
reading_mnemonic: You have a top hat and all the clothes that go with it but you <kanji>also</kanji> need a nice <reading>ca</reading>r (か) too! You can't just get all dressed up and then have no way to get anywhere to show it off.

meaning_mnemonic: You're <radical>sick</radical> because you put an <radical>arrow</radical> in your <radical>mouth</radical> and tried to eat it. To be honest, that's just really <kanji>stupid</kanji>. You have to be stupid to try to eat an arrow. You deserve to be sick.
reading_mnemonic: The only way to cure this serious case of <kanji>stupid</kanji> is to make you eat <reading>chee</reading>se (ち). Not only will it fix your sick stomach by cushioning all the arrows that you shoved in your stupid mouth, but it should send smart cheese waves to your brain and cure you of that stupid all together.

meaning_mnemonic: You see a <radical>mouth</radical> coming out of the top of a <radical>tree</radical> so you go into <kanji>shock</kanji>. Your brain just can't comprehend what's in front of you.
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>shock</kanji> you've suffered results in you needing to stay <reading>ho</reading>me (ほう) from now on. You don't get to travel, explore, or even get groceries. You're homebound from now on, buddy.

meaning_mnemonic: After your <radical>wedding</radical> you have a baby and it uses its <radical>mouth</radical> to <kanji>suckle</kanji> from your post-wedding boobs. Yes, babies <kanji>nurse</kanji> from breasts. Get over it, kids.
reading_mnemonic: The baby wants to <kanji>nurse</kanji> all day and the only thing you can seem to do at the same time is <reading>hoe</reading> (ほ) your garden. You hold the baby to your breast with one arm and hoe little rows with the other. It's actually a great workout and a nice way to spend time!

meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>leader</radical> managed to find the right <radical>direction</radical> home using marks in the <radical>dirt</radical> in the middle of <radical>winter</radical>. This makes you so <kanji>proud</kanji>! You're proud because this resourceful leader is YOUR resourceful leader.
reading_mnemonic: This leader you're so <kanji>proud</kanji> of is none other than Grandpa <reading>ごう</reading>いち. He's been getting a bit slow over the years, and you really didn't think he'd make it back. But, by gum, he did it.

meaning_mnemonic: When you leave <radical>flowers</radical> on a <radical>tombstone</radical> they look good at first, but after a few days or some harsh weather, there's nothing left but <kanji>stem</kanji>s. That's why you have to replace flowers on tombstones all the time. If you don't it will look like you only left the stems there, and that's pretty disrespectful.
reading_mnemonic: You have an idea that can make these tombstones look better than just having leftover <kanji>stem</kanji>s all over them. You brought <reading>cookie</reading>s (くき)! Cookies don't fall apart in the wind, and everyone loves cookies, alive or dead. You replace the stems with the cookies and everything looks a lot nicer.

meaning_mnemonic: You see a <radical>building</radical> with a <radical>lip ring</radical> and it's just so cute you have to <kanji>flatter</kanji> it. "That lip ring looks wonderful on you, Buildingさん," you say.
reading_mnemonic: The building is <kanji>flatter</kanji>ed and you hear it shout, "<reading>Ah</reading> (あ)!" and blush. The entire building turns red.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>leader</radical> who usually hits you with a <radical>stick</radical> in <radical>winter</radical> finds it in his <radical>heart</radical> to give you some <kanji>leisure</kanji> time.
reading_mnemonic: You're just about to start your <kanji>leisure</kanji> time when a group of <reading>you</reading>ths (ゆう) appears with their own sticks. You look back for the leader, and he's wearing a bathrobe, sunglasses, and is drinking some hot cocoa. Wait... this is leisure time for... HIM?! OH NO!

meaning_mnemonic: What does a <radical>tree</radical> make that you'd want to put in your <radical>mouth</radical>? An <kanji>apricot</kanji>! Apricots are also about the size of an open mouth, so they kind of look like mouths hanging down under the trees. You can bite them right off the tree with your own mouth!
reading_mnemonic: After you put the <kanji>apricot</kanji> in your mouth you realize that this tastes really familiar, but not pleasant. It tastes just like the <reading>an</reading>chovies (あん) from the <reading>zoo</reading> (ず) smell. How did that happen? You don't like apricots anymore.

meaning_mnemonic: What kind of <radical>flowers</radical> grow in the <radical>west</radical>? <kanji>Rose madder</kanji> flowers, of course. Don't know what those are? That's okay. Just know their roots are used to make dyes of a <kanji>deep red</kanji> color. Red like the rose in their name, but madder, wilder, deeper… And they grow in the west so they can take in those deep red colors of the setting sun.
reading_mnemonic: As you smash the roots of the <kanji>rose madder</kanji> and stain your fingers a <kanji>deep red</kanji>, a little girl comes up to you and points. She says, "<reading>赤ね</reading> (あかね)?" (That's red, right?) You look down at the rose madder roots and your fingers, and nod. She's right, it is red. Deep red.

meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Dry</radical> an already <radical>dry</radical> <radical>tree</radical> to create a <kanji>bookmark</kanji>. The more you dry the tree, the flatter it becomes, making it the perfect way to mark your spot in a book without needing to fold a page or write on it.
reading_mnemonic: What are you bookmarking anyway? Look down and see yourself putting one of the tree <kanji>bookmark</kanji>s on a page in your notebook that says "<reading>She owe</reading>s me <reading>ree</reading>ds (しおり)." Oh yeah, you had to make this bookmark in the first place because your friend took your reed bookmarks and didn't give them back.
